title: Vibe Coding: The Revolutionary Approach Transforming Software Development

highlights.highlight: At its core, vibe coding represents a fundamental shift in the developer-machine relationship. Rather than manually crafting every line yourself, you collaborate with AI that generates the actual code implementation. This extends beyond just writing functions—it encompasses the entire software creation life cycle, where AI becomes your partner in brainstorming architecture, researching solutions, implementing features, crafting tests, and hardening security.

Vibe coding fundamentally changes the relationship between developers and machines. Rather than manually crafting every line of code by hand, developers collaborate with AI to generate the actual code
“I just talkâ€¦I barely even touch the keyboard. I ask for the dumbest things like ‘decrease the padding on the sidebar by half’ because I’m too lazy to find it.”

Kim and Yegge explain that in vibe coding, you become “the orchestrator rather than the executor, directing rather than typing, allowing AI to shoulder the implementation burden while you focus on vision and verification.”
Kim and Yegge introduce what they call “the good FAAFO” (fast, ambitious, autonomous, fun, O\optionality).
Fast: Vibe coding dramatically compresses development timelines, with tasks that once took months now completed in days or even hours.
Ambitious: The lowered implementation cost reshapes what developers consider possible. Projects previously deemed too complex or time-consuming become achievable
Autonomous: Vibe coding allows you to do work autonomously, often being able to complete things that previously required multiple people or teams

Fun: By automating tedious tasks like debugging syntax errors, wrestling with unfamiliar libraries, and writing boilerplate code, vibe coding restores the creative joy of programming that drew many to the field initially.
Fun: By automating tedious tasks like debugging syntax errors, wrestling with unfamiliar libraries, and writing boilerplate code
Optionality: Perhaps most transformative is the ability to explore multiple solutions simultaneously rather than committing to a single approach.
even when the AI occasionally struggled, the human-AI partnership proved remarkably effective at overcoming obstacles that neither could have solved as efficiently alone.
vibe coding redefines the developer role from manual coder to strategic orchestrator

title: NPC Streaming | Know Your Meme

highlights.highlight: One of the earliest known TikTok Live streamers to do NPC streams is @natuecoco, a Japanese TikToker. During her livestreams, she often acts like a video game NPC by lightly bouncing or performing what looks like an ""idle animation,"" only reacting when she's given a gift.

NPC Streaming, also known as NPC Trend, is a type of TikTok LIVE stream in which the streamer acts or is perceived as acting like a video game NPC by mimicking idle animations, only saying something or performing a specific action when gifted, the action or phrase changing depending on the gift.

title: It's Not a Game! Rules of Notice and Hermeneutics of Suspicion in Contemporary FMV Games - Inge van de Ven, 2024

highlights.highlight: This article reflects on the resurgence of Full Motion Video (FMV) games, focusing on Her Story (2015), The Infectious Madness of Dr Dekker (2017), Telling Lies (2019), Contradiction (2015), and The Shapeshifting Detective (2018).

They rely on the player's imagination in suturing the images together and in forming an empathetic understanding of the main characters’ actions and motivations. By virtue of this lack, FMV games challenges players’ analytical and hermeneutic abilities and further cognitive patience.
An absence of “rules of notice” by which the details in a narrative are hierarchically organized, including editing and other attention-guiding devices, is part of these games’ procedural rhetoric.

title: Counter-gaming | Alexander R. Galloway

highlights.highlight: RTS games focus on a multi-nodal ecosystem of flows and factories, resources and expenditures, secure zones and hostile frontiers. The RTS genre is thus informatic capitalism pure and simple. The genre displays how informatic media and informatic labor are essentially coterminous in today’s world.

A somewhat nefarious miasma lingers in all of this, for the labor of the web surfer or the gamer or the blogger goes unpaid, even while exploited by other parties. Thus within the sphere of gaming, we are obligated to come to terms with a new kind of unpaid labor, a new kind of economy.

labor today is often simply donated as a “gift” to the economy. This will be the ultimate tragic denouement of the rise of gaming, of the democratization of play, of social media, of open-source software: it will result in the open-sourcing of all labor; the demand for “volunteer” workers will metastasize across all spheres of public life.
The Web is, in this sense, the world's largest sweat shop, for it is the site of most unpaid labor in the world today.

To formulate this same observation in psychoanalytic terminology: previous mass media formats -- cinema famously -- were fundamentally masochistic; new media however are fundamentally sadistic, in that they require the labor of manipulation, selection, transformation and command over objects (data objects, commodities, behaviors, life forms, and of course other human beings)
In this way, if previous media formats disciplined human beings into becoming better workers, today’s informatic media liberate human beings so they may become better bosses

remember how Brain Age for the Nintendo DS was all the rage a few years ago. In years to come we will see a steady rise in games devoted to informatic therapy and training. This is but one harbinger of the coming gamic class being cultivated today.

Hence a lament for the new informatic masters: we desperately need alternative algorithms; we desperately need counter-gaming. But, thus far, alternative algorithms seem hopelessly impossible, beyond the very horizon of intelligibility.
These days play looks more like labor, and labor looks more like play.
We still need alternative algorithms, now more than ever. But what would such algorithms look like?

The alternative algorithms of countergaming are either structured as negation or as deprivation. With negation, the game is stripped of all possibilities of game play, left to lapse back to other media altogether (video, animation). With deprivation, the game is censored and scolded, allowed to continue to play, but only in an enlightened or “self-aware” mode.
the very essence of what makes a game a game is withheld, deferred either for all time, or just for a moment.

For one must never forget that there is an important utopian possibility contained within any type of aesthetic failure. Or as Jean-Jacques Rousseau wrote in his “Discourse on the Arts and Sciences” of 1750: failure has an infinity of forms, but the truth is singular.
Today we should take this as a celebration not a lament, and focus on the failure not the truth. Counter-gaming shall have an infinity of forms.
let's demilitarize play; let's uncouple gaming from the mandates of the market; let's dial up the game studies and dial down the game theory.
Counter-gaming

title: Playing God | Broadcast

highlights.highlight: Interactive cinema isn’t a game.
I’m Your Man, the first mainstream interactive movie
“Whenever you get an opportunity to be involved in something new, you might as well be in on it,” he said. “Even if it goes the way of 3D glasses and Odorama.”

Following Ebert’s logic, if a movie is meant to act on its audience, then a game is the inverse: an invitation for the audience to act. Of course, within the confines of a “game” like Mr. Payback or I’m Your Man, that invitation is limited to predetermined decision points. But even in the more open sandbox of a modern video game, there are boundaries on action—in fact, those boundaries are what define the form

C. Thi Nguyen observes, all games have rules and obstacles, imposed to constrain player agency. And games are, he argues, the art of agency. “As stories let us record narratives,” Nguyen writes, “games let us record agencies,” encoding them into “artifactual vessels” that can be passed around and temporarily embodied by others
I have the sense that Ebert’s curmudgeonly take was the right one: an interactive movie is not a movie. But it isn’t a game, either

title: REMAKE, REMEDIATION, REENACTMENT | VRAL

highlights.highlight: Jonas Blume’s The Good, the Bad, and the Rock (2023, above) and Transporter (2023) are video works that restage iconic cinematic moments through visual mimicry that foregrounds the absence of human performers.
Both pieces replicate camera movement and editing patterns from their sources but remove and erase the protagonists who once anchored the action

Reconstructing The Good, the Bad, and the Rock or Transporter inside a game engine would not dilute their meaning. It would extend their critical gesture and postmodern nature. Blume’s work interrogates the reconfiguration of visual landmarks the imaginary and the disintegration of cinematic reference. This approach is central to Blume’s wildly original practice, where past forms flicker without resolution, forever suspended in the logic of simulation.
Possible exercise for Game Art courses  Exercise Title: Reenacting the remake: from index to code Â

Students will engage with machinima as a form of conceptual reenactment, examining how narrative memory and genre codes can be evoked through spatial and audiovisual logic alone.

title: THE KISS, THE GLITCH AND THE AVATAR: LOVE IN THE AGE OF MMOG | VRAL

highlights.highlight: “The story of love that takes place in the online game World of Warcraft,” Juan explains, “is turned into the raw material to explain how players construct their own virtual bodies in the digital world and how their bodies are extended in digital form.” This extension is not symbolic or abstract; it is enacted through gestures of touching, embracing, and kissing, performed between avatars of different (fantasy) races.

the screen does not merely separate player from character: it enables a traversal, a crossing, in which visuality and interaction generate the illusion, and perhaps the experience, of bodily connection.

A fundamental question lies at the core of It Was Just a Virtual Kiss: how do we navigate the virtual-physical dichotomy in digital media? In this context, I would argue that digital touch has a form of materiality, but not in the conventional sense that we associate with physical touch. Instead, it emerges at the intersection of phenomenological, affective, and technological processes.

The avatar, then, is not a substitute for the body, but a “hybrid embodiment, in which the player’s corporeal dimension is digitally integrated into a different space and resonates with the movements and emotional states of their digital avatar.”Â
Juan conceptualises glitches not as technical errors to be corrected, but as aesthetic and conceptual tools for revealing the instability of this peculiar form of incarnation

Instead of presenting the avatar as a seamless extension of the self in McLuhanian terms, Juan exposes its composite nature, assembled from overlapping gestures, interface logics, and networked interactions.Â

Machinima absolutely has the potential to subvert the rigid gender binaries and normative identities embedded in gaming culture – structures that are reinforced by systemic oppression. At the same time, it remains haunted by the very logic of the systems it emerges from. However, the act of exposing these logics – through recycling, remixing, and recontextualizing game assets – is itself a form of resistance. Both within and beyond these systems, creators can reveal cracks and contradictions, opening up new spaces for alternative modes of representation and interaction. While we may never fully escape the influence of these structures, engaging with queerness – playing with, against, and through the rules of these systems – can generate new ways of being and imagining that challenge the status quo.
he identifies romance not as an anomaly in a game of conquest, but as an infrastructural misuse: a form of resistance enacted through misaligned or creative use of combat mechanics.

Assim como os arquivos de baixa resoluí§ão de Steyerl, os primeiros bancos de dados de pornografia amadora circulavam incessantemente, desvinculados de sua origem ou autoria.

A intervení§ão de Miranda cruza claramente com o conceito de olhar masculino de Laura Mulvey, demonstrando como o jogo fetichiza um tipo de corpo feminino estreito, mesmo em seus detalhes invisí­veis.

Miranda destaca como a estética da mercadoria e o desejo se entrelaí§am nos ní­veis mais granulares do design: as imagens servem ao olhar masculino, mas o enquadramento invasivo de Miranda drena essa intení§ão erótica, revelando apenas uma uniformidade poligonal.

Paradoxalmente, Underw[h]e(a)re sugere que a verdadeira ficí§ão de Assassin's Creed: Unity não é sua grandiosa reconstruí§ão histórica ou sua fidelidade arquitetônica ao ""real"", mas a fantasia de diferení§a que ele alega encenar. Ao expor essas intimidades repetitivas e superficialmente codificadas, Miranda demonstra que a construí§ão de mundo mais consistente do jogo é, em íºltima análise, um compromisso com a mesmice — um espetáculo uniforme de desejo disfarí§ado de variedade.

title: LUDIC HAUNTOLOGY, DEFERRED CONNECTION | VRAL

highlights.highlight: Though formally dissimilar, both use video games not as entertainment or spectacle but to show how the political and the affective are routed through simulation’s infrastructural systems

Giath Taha’s Becoming a Ghost (2022), screened on VRAL between August 30 and September 12 2023, documents a virtual reunion between two brothers separated by war and exile. Set entirely within PlayerUnknown’s Battlegrounds (PUBG), the work resists violence, focusing instead on acts of wandering, care, and quiet resistance.

Jonathan Millet’s Les fantômes (Ghost Trail, 2024) is a thriller centred on Hamid (Adam Bessa), a Syrian exile in Strasbourg, who uses a multiplayer war game to update members of an underground network about the whereabouts of an alleged former torturer now living under an assumed identity

the video game in Fantômes functions as an infrastructure of concealment: a camouflaged protocol where violence is simulated and strategic operations are hidden in plain sight. Hamid and his cohort do not play for recreation; using assumed names, they track fugitives and share updates during multiplayer sessions. The interface—avatars, voice chat, and devastated environments—allows for identity checks and coordinated actions while maintaining plausible deniability
the game’s internal logic mirrors the asylum process: action must follow verification, and haste may unravel everything

The procedural structure of the game substitutes for institutions and bureaucracy, while replicating their opacity and constraint. If the game appears as a high-intensity third-person shooter, the real stakes it obscures are calculated, protracted, and deeply consequential
Where Les fantômes prioritises verification and delay, Taha suspends those logics entirely
Becoming a Ghost offers a starkly different use of the game architecture and interface
He does not aim to win or deceive, conquer or destroy, but to remain present with his brother
Becoming a Ghost suspends that logic, opting instead for ambient drift and affective openness through counter-gaming

The so-called “magic circle” collapses here: rather than an insulated sphere of norms, outcomes and make-believe, the game functions as a real-time infrastructure for personal and collective manoeuvre

title: VRAL 93: Giath Taha — MILAN MACHINIMA FESTIVAL

highlights.highlight: Separated for ten years due to the Syrian conflict, Taha and his brother reconnect in this digital warzone, which mirrors the real-life violence that forced Taha to flee Syria. Although the game involves players competing to be the last one standing, it paradoxically becomes a safe space for the brothers to discuss topics censored elsewhere. The work explores themes of presence and absence, reality and simulation, and how virtual spaces can offer temporary escape from harsh realities

The relationship between video gaming and geopolitical issues is deeply intertwined and layered. Many games are set in real locations or engage with real geopolitical tensions, often as a form of soft power, cultural influence, or even propaganda

PUBG, its popularity in Syria can be attributed to two main factors. Firstly, the game’s graphics are relatively modest compared to the sound design, meaning that players don’t need high-end devices like the Xbox Series X or PlayStation 5 to participate – a typical mobile phone is sufficient. This accessibility is crucial

PUBG’s popularity lies in the lived experiences of players. Many of them are profoundly affected by the geopolitical realities of the Middle East, including the oppressive conditions in Syria. For these players, PUBG offers an escape – a shift from a dystopian reality controlled by oppressors to a virtual space that, while similar, provides an alternative existence. It’s a way to momentarily leave behind the harsh realities of their surroundings
This desire to escape is why so many players bring their backgrounds and political realities into the game
virtual world becomes a place to process, and perhaps temporarily avoid, the oppressive situations they face daily
From Heidegger’s perspective, being is not fully present in any single moment. It’s an interplay of presence and absence, involving both the past and the present
Derrida, on the other hand, argues that presence is never fully attainable; it’s always deferred through a chain of signifiers, making his approach more linguistic
Building on these ideas, being thrown into a war zone and being distracted by the manifestations of conflict allows authenticity to emerge

I consciously chose not to fight or engage in what the game – or the platform – demanded of me. The authenticity of the other person, in this case, my brother, also surfaced in this context. He used to play the game almost daily, but when we met online after twelve years, the game transformed for him. It became less about playing and more about protecting his younger brother, who had annoyingly decided not to carry a weapon in a shooting game
To tie this back to Heidegger, the moment was an interplay between presence and absence

I think it’s crucial to remember that video games, especially online ones, are essentially interactive systems. The designers set up the rules, defining the framework within which players can operate. This setup often limits the players' freedom, making them subject to the designers’ choices. In a way, this can resemble a form of authoritarian control. Players can interact with the game, but only within the confines of the system, leading to specific actions and predetermined outcomes
I completely agree with your observation that video games are promoted as open worlds – spaces of possibilities and freedom

The line between virtuality and reality is very thin, and I didn’t want to be trapped by the same mechanisms of control. So, my defense mechanism was to be a pacifist in the game, resisting what the game’s designers expected me to do.
When players engage with video games, they seek an alternative virtual space, but they inevitably bring their real-life complexities with them

important aspect of gaming is its immersive experience. However, this immersion is temporary – it doesn’t last forever. That’s why escapism is not absolute or definitive; it’s transient and limited, often ending when players return to their real lives

title: THE AESTHETICS OF SLOW MACHINIMA (2 of 4) — GAME VIDEO/ART. A SURVEY

highlights.highlight: These auteurs operate in the gray area separating cinema, animation, gaming, and performance art, contributing in their own way to blur the boundaries of each practice. I argued that this certain formal trend in contemporary machinima can be seen as an act of cultural resistance, a resistance to speed, frenzy, and acceleration.
Philip Solomon’s EMPIRE
Justin Remes’s (2015) definition “cinema of stasis”, which he uses to refer to those “films in which stasis—not motion—is the default.”
static films occupy a special place in film history as they lie at the intersection of several different genres and media, e.g.Â painting and photography

“Static films offer radical challenges to conventional conceptions of cinema, since they are ostensibly motion pictures without motion.” He adds that “these films foreground stasis and consequently blur the lines between traditional visual art and motion pictures.”
these cinematic productions address Walter Benjamin’s observation about the screen vs. canvas dichotomy.
“The Work of Art in the Age of Its Technological Reproducibility"" (1936)

“The painting invites the viewer to contemplation; before it, he can give himself up to his train of associations. Before a film image, he cannot do so. No sooner has he seen it than it has already changed. It cannot be fixed on.”

Genevieve Yue (2012) wrote in Film Comment, “EMPIRE” [...]Â amounts to a full day, passing through rain, sunset, night, and, come the following afternoon, the return of stormy weather.. [...]Â Perched on a skyscraper ledge, in an elaborate choreography of avatar, camera, and encoded “cheats,” Solomon allows us to gaze, as Warhol did, at the building across the way: “Rotterdam Tower,” or what is more recognizable as the Empire State Building.""

“EMPIRE” [...]Â amounts to a full day, passing through rain, sunset, night, and, come the following afternoon, the return of stormy weather.. [...]Â Perched on a skyscraper ledge, in an elaborate choreography of avatar, camera, and encoded “cheats,” Solomon allows us to gaze, as Warhol did, at the building across the way: “Rotterdam Tower,” or what is more recognizable as the Empire State Building.""
Remes argues that Warhol’s main goal in filming Empire was “to see time go by.”

In his monograph on Andrei Tarkovsky's 1979 sci-fi film Stalker, Zona: A Book about a Film about a Journey to a Room, Geoff Dyer (2012), observes that ""every second [of Antonioni’s L’avventura]Â lasted a minute, every minute lasted an hour"".

The real subject of Solomon's film is not ""action"", but time. As Remes explains, “The spectator of a film like [Warhol’s] Empire witnesses movement: not the movement of the building on the screen but the movement of time itself.”

By foregrounding stasis, films like Empire actually make the spectator more aware of the movement of time and consciousness, neither of which can be apprehended in the same way when one is absorbed in the movement of a cinematic image.

title: THE AESTHETICS OF SLOW MACHINIMA (1 of 4) — GAME VIDEO/ART. A SURVEY

highlights.highlight: “I’ve always liked to watch people play video games. Or to watch video games as cinema. So when you start watching video games as cinema and you start considering them cinemaâ€¦ It becomes so unlike anything you’ve seen in cinema that it’s kinda interesting.” (Cory Arcangel, 2011)

In his “State of Cinema” address at the 46th San Francisco Film Festival, French critic Michel Ciment (2003) described the emergence of a new cinematic style,Â “a cinema of slowness, of contemplation”. One year later, British critic Jonathan Romney coined the now popular expression “Slow Cinema” in a review to indicate those films that deliberately reject the narrative and aesthetic conventions of mainstream productions (1)
Slow cinema emphasizes long takes and extended durations. Observational in nature, it uses subdued visual techniques and minimal narrative strategies.
Ira Jaffe (2014) writes in Slow Movies: Countering the Cinema of Action
“The plot and dialogue in slow movies often gravitate towards stillness and death, and tend, in any case, to be minimal, indeterminate and unresolved” (p. 23)

David Campany (2007) slow films began as an avant-garde practice (consider, for instance, the Situationists) and represented a counterpoint to the “mass distraction” of advertising, television, and popular culture
Lav Diaz, Pedro Costa, Lisandro Alonso, Ben Rivers, Carlos Reygadas, Bela Tarr, Apichatpong Weerasethakul, Tsai Ming-liang, Kelly Reichardt
Justin Remes (2015) has called “cinema of stasis”

“slow machinima” is an international effort, fiercely independent, and deliberately adversarial to the dominant paradigm. Slow machinima productions are generally indifferent or deliberately antagonistic to mainstream game audiences, and perhaps, to mainstream audiences in general.
In many ways, slow machinima is a gesture of coordinated resistance to contemporary game culture and its testosterone-driven aesthetics, hype cycles, and overt misogyny.

In its rejection of gaming instant gratification, slow machinima chronicles the spaces and times of inactivity and “in-betweenness” of mainstream productions, those sparse moments of tranquility of otherwise fast and furious “triple AAA titles” or “franchises”

If most video games can be situated in the accelerationist paradigm - itself a manifestation of capitalism’ obsession for growth, speed, and grotesque excess - slow machinima invokes a more reflective, attentive, and introspective viewing experience
Lutz Koepnick (2014) writes in On Slowness: Toward an Aesthetic of the Contemporary

Our attention spans shrink toward zero because we have to make too many decisions within ever shorter windows of time. Cell phones, handheld computers, and ubiquitous screening devices urge us to be always on and produce instantaneous responses, yet we no longer take the time to contemplate an image, develop a profound thought, traverse a gorgeous landscape, play a game, or follow the intensity of some emotion. (p. 12)

Slow machinima can be seen as alternative to a constant flow of interruptions, inane updates, and juvenile distractions.Â In terms of presentation, distribution, and circulation, slow machinima diverge from fandom productions insofar as they are not usually distributed
prefers projection rooms to smartphone screens, art galleries’ video installation to laptops.
